Student Essay:
The first episode of the documentary series, Language Families of the World, is an introduction to the process of derivation of languages and how languages have changed over the span of humanity. Dr. McWhorter expands on the many aspects of language, including the inherent need for a language to change and how that change is inevitable (6:15). When a group of people speaking the same language get separated for a long time, the way each group speaks that language changes over time. Similarly, language changes over generations as each generation pronounces sounds differently. Dr. McWhorter expands on this by explaining how the different syllables of the word “sock” can transform into different sounds. This is an example of sound change, one the many processes by which words change over time.

The other way a language can transform is by the addition of new material such as suffixes and prefixes. He gives an example of the word ‘slowly’ where the suffix ‘-ly’ was derived from the word ‘like’. Meaning changes can also transform one language into another as a word’s original meaning changes over time to represent different things. An interesting example is how the words ‘merry’, ‘bra’ and ‘pretzel’ all trace back to one word in Ukrainian which meant ‘short’. This happened through not just meaning changes in the original Ukrainian word but also in sound changes over time. This is something that I observed in this segment of the video: certain words can go through multiple processes of transformation at the same time.

The reason why this segment of the video stood out to me is because how I speak my native tongue Bengali in comparison to my parents’ generation and the ones before them. I had noticed that my peers and I use newer words and certain words in a completely different way than them. I used to believe that our way of speaking was inherently harming the language by not conserving it properly but now I understand that change of language is inevitable. While conservation of language is necessary, there is no right way of using it as it will change over time.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi [student], this is a thoughtful essay. You did a good job summarizing the three key mechanisms of language change, and your reflection on your use of newly developed terms isn't harming the Bengali language, but participating in its evolution is a sophisticated insight! 

For future assignments, I'd love to see more specific examples from your personal experience. For example, you mentioned that you use words differently from your parents -  which words specifically? 

Also, please proofread for typos; you wrote 'one the many' instead of 'one of the many.'

Student Essay:
After watching this film, I found many things interesting, and learned about many topics that
were completely new to me. In particular, (“Why are there so many Languages?” S1. E1. 13 minutes 45
seconds), Dr McWorther states how the words “merry”, “bra” and “pretzel” all trace back to a distant
English ancestor. He begins to draw the connection from a Ukrainian word that no longer exists. This
word stood for “short”, however English did not exist at the time. This word then went on to become
“merry” in the English language due to the connection of something being short existing as a positive
outcome. The Ukrainian word then changes even more over time, leading to the creation of the word
“bra”. After this, the sounds change even further leading to the creation of the word “pretzel”, which
connects to crossed arms, and brachial. I found this very interesting due to personally assuming these
languages to be nothing alike. The concept of these commonly used English words all being developed
from the same origin of a Ukrainian word that no longer exists is very surprising. Without this video, I
would have never thought that “pretzel” and “merry” come from an origin that is anything but close to
each other. I am further intrigued by this connection due to personally being born in Ukraine, and learning
Russian (part of the East Slavic family, like Ukranian) and English simultaneously. Growing up, I was
able to slowly learn and make connections across both languages. As I am now, more developed, I can
really reflect on these connections and see how important the change of sound is in a language. For
example “mathematics” in English has a similar sound to the pronunciation of “matematika” in Russian.
We can also see the opposite using another example, such as “tree” in English, and the Russian
pronunciation being “derevo”. The sounds are completely different, even when they mean the same word,
which is not like the case for the word “mathematics”. Furthermore, being corrected by my family for my
improper pronunciation of some Russian words shows a connection between how each individual can
change the sounds of a language, leading to overall change in hundreds of years. Conclusively, I found
this video very interesting, especially the point about how three english words today came from an origin
that is my birthplace.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Diana, great job providing a wonderful personal reflection. Your connection to the material (being born in Ukraine and learning Russian and English simultaneously) offered such a unique insight. 

For the future assignments, please proofread your writing, specifically in terms of spelling (e.g., McWorther --> McWhorter), capitalization (e.g., englihs --> English). Also, try to use 'In conclusion' rather than 'Conclusively' to end your essay, as 'conclusively' usually means 'decisively' rather than 'finally.'

Student Essay:
After viewing the film, I found a lot of what Dr McWhorter had to say to be very interesting and I
learned a lot of new facts. Towards the end of that film (video 1, 24 min 47 seconds), he stated that “the
click languages are not just click sounds, and those sounds that we hear are just as important as our own
consonants and vowels are”(McWhorter). He also made a point after giving an example of what a word

keyboard and woke up to an accidental typo. He states that in North America, a lot of their sentences can
be contained in just a single word. For us English speakers, that doesn’t add up because there is no
separation, and it all looks like a big mess. But for them, there are pieces to that blob that add up and
create meaning for them. I find this so intriguing due to the fact that I am so used to reading words that
have vowels and consonants, which build into a word, and I can’t seem to figure out how all those
consonants add up to create meaning. Who built that lnagauge and started that? How did someone just
make that up? It is so cool how many languages we have in this world today, yet they are different, but
they all relate to each other. Each language connects, and it all started from just one singular language. A
connection I can draw for a personal experience is when I was learning how to play sports when I was
younger. There were so many terms and slang that were used, and I was so confused because my mind
wasn’t trained to translate them. After a lot of practice and repetition, I got used to that norm and realized
that it all made sense and everything connected ot one another. When I was in the sports environment and
playing and practicing, I would use that certain vocab on a daily basis because it became a norm, but as
soon as I would leave or go home, I would switch to the words I would use normally. I think that the

used to having things be out of the ordinary. The more you practice, the better you will get at something
and the more comfortable you will be.

Student Essay:
In Language Families of the World, at the 19:30 mark, Dr. McWhorter discusses the
Language Family Tree, providing an overview of the world’s language families in the form of
a global tour - one continent at a time. I found this part of the film intriguing as it gives a
visual demonstration of the clustering of specific related languages. It was interesting to
see on a map how proximity plays into a language’s development and eventual splitting off
into another related language. It also aids me in understanding the vastness of the world’s
languages: as Dr. McWhortner presents at the outset of the film, there are 7,000 languages
in the world (or 6,000, as is Dr. McWhortner’s preferred estimate) but that is such large
number it is difficult to comprehend the reality of there being so many languages spoken in
the world. However, seeing it presented as a break-down into language families helps me
to grasp the information in a way that is concrete rather than conceptual. For instance,
living here in the United States, it is surprising to know that there are 10 language families
here. The map presented in the film shows there is a language family that stretches across
Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and into Northern Florida. This is especially interesting to
me as I visited Mobile, Alabama in 2023 and learned that it had a very similar history as
New Orleans. Seeing that the two cities share the same language family helps me connect
this information to the fascinating history of the region and I am better able to imagine and
comprehend the people speaking the languages, not just an abstract number of
languages.
Another amazing example presented in the film is that New Guinea, a small island in
Oceania, has 25 language families. How many languages are in each language family, and
how many total languages are there in that land? How and why did New Guinea become so
linguistically diverse? How many speakers are there of each language? Dr. McWhorter
does not discuss the answers to these specific questions in the film, but provides enough
information to illicit curiosity and engagement, which I enjoyed and found interesting
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Alexix, you did a great job connecting the map visualization to your personal travels in the US. 

For your next assignments, be careful with typos and word choices. You consistently misspelled the professor's name as "McWhortner," and you used the word "illicit" (which means illegal or forbidden) when you likely meant "elicit." 

Finally, regarding your point about Alabama and Louisiana: the map Dr. McWhorter shows refers to indigenous language families, whereas the "shared history" of Mobile and New Orleans usually refers to French/Spanish colonialism.

Student Essay:
At 18:04, Dr. McWorther begins to talk about the English dialect of "Black Country English," that was spoken in the west midlands of America and is special specifically because it is an example of a dialect that wasn't written down and changed a lot as a result. It's name originates from what McWorther says is "coal dust" which has lead me to assume - since McWorther didn't emphasize this point too greatly -  that this was a dialect spoken specifically by coal miners back when that was a common industry in America. 

Black Country English developed in such a way that it began to sound like another language entirely, with the video going so far as to compare it to Norwegian. Many of the words that are in the past tense or that are conjugations got shortened into word that seem either heavily accented or like totally different words. One example of this is the word "gave" morphing into "Gid". 

While this specific dialect is interesting, I'm mostly interested in what it represents, which is how language can be changed by things like culture and other outside factors. In this case, English was altered by a lack of literacy/lack of people writing things down which led to a whole new dialect. While there are instances of languages changing just as a result of time and human error or imperfection (which is discussed earlier in the video when McWorther talks about sound changes eventually changing how words are said) I know from my own knowledge and observation of language that there are many things that can effect how we talk to one another and I find that very interesting. One personal example is how some of the slang that I've seen develop over the course of my life has become a legitimate, or at the very least more commonly used, part of the english language. Being able to study this pattern in other cultures is something I find very interesting.

Student Essay:
Watching the first episode of Language Families of the World, I found especially intriguing what Dr. McWhorter had to say about meaning changes at 13:33. He was talking about how words’ meanings are drifting into being new ones all the time, and I can’t agree more with him on that statement. The changes that happen reflect the cultural shifts, social attitudes, and historical events.

When I think about meaning change, I think about my native Ukrainian language. Over time, many words have gained different meanings that can be different from their original ones. Such as the word “подонок”, which was originally used to refer to the literal bottom of an item, and is now used to describe a morally corrupt or despicable person. Another example is the word “бидло”, which used to mean cattle, but has now evolved into a derogatory term for people considered rude or uncultured. While those changes happened decades before I was born, some gained their new meanings in recent years, after the full-scale invasion. Such as “бавовна”, which traditionally referred to cotton, has taken on an ironic meaning associated with explosions on the enemy’s territory. “Кіборг”  is now a symbol of extraordinary resilience and heroism in Ukrainian soldiers. And the word “орки”, once tied mainly to fantasy literature, is now used as a synonym for the enemy, carrying strong emotional and political meaning.

These examples are proof of Dr. McWorter’s point that the meaning change is inevitable. As society changes, everything around it changes to assimilate; humans need to adapt the meanings of the words or come up with new ones.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Valeriia, your examples of semantic shift in Ukrainian are absolutely fascinating and highly relevant. 

However, your essay is too short (266 words) and falls below the 300-word minimum. You need to expand your analysis to meet the requirements. Also, watch out for sentence fragments: you started two sentences with "Such as..." "Such as" is a connector, so it should join the previous sentence or start a complete thought (e.g., "One such example is..."). Finally, you misspelled the professor's name as "McWorter."

Student Essay: Language Families of the World is a documentary that introduces the concept of languages and is narrated by Dr. John McWorther, a linguist and author. At video 1, 7 min 19 seconds, Dr. McWorther brings up an idea where “Each generation pronounces sound slightly differently. And then it’s like a game of telephone or operator… after a while you’ve got a complete transformation.” Now this can occur in multiple areas of language, but Dr.McWorther goes in depth on sounds changing. I find this interesting because it’s as if we’re playing telephone in real life. As each generation learns a new word in their language, the pronunciation of different words slightly changes with each generation. With each slight change in pronunciation, the word eventually sounds quite different from the word that language started with. In this situation, a new generation is another person in the game of telephone. I also find it interesting because I relate to the fact in my personal life. My family speaks malayalam fluently and I can understand malayalam. I’m not entirely fluent in malayalam, though I can speak a few words in malayalam. When I pronounce “shower”, “water”, or “rice” in malayalam, it doesn't sound the same as when my mother pronounces it. While I don’t pronounce it the same, it can be understood by others. All in all, I pronounce words in malayalam slightly differently than my mother who is in a different generation than me. My grandparents pronounce words in malayalam slightly differently than my parents, siblings, and myself. I’ve also seen this occur in my life when I was learning Spanish. There would be fluent Spanish speakers in my class and their pronunciation of certain words would be slightly different than that of the teacher’s pronunciation. To understand this phenomenon, “slightly” is the operative word. The changes in sounds have to sound similar, otherwise the individual is just not pronouncing the word correctly in the given language.
Teacher Feedback:

Student Essay:
One topic that Dr. John McWhorter discusses in the film that I find particularly intriguing is  the language family tree, and it's really interesting what it is able to reveal about human movement and history. This discussion appears at approximately 19 minutes and 33 seconds, when he introduces how linguistics organizes language into different families.
In this section of the film, Dr. McWhorter explains that languages diversify over time as different human populations migrate. Rather than remaining stagnant, languages gradually split, change, and develop into whole new languages. New forms are also created, which morph into different, distinct language families. Linguists are able to trace these relationships by identifying shared structure, sounds, and vocabulary that all lead back to a certain common ancestral language. The result of this is a family-tree model that visually represents how languages are historically connected.
What I found most interesting about this explanation is how it challenged my idea that just because a country is close to another, they share similar languages. I previously assumed that languages spoken near one another were related, but I couldn't be more wrong. This segment showed me that history, migration, and periods of separation between countries matter much more than the simple location. I realized after this that language diversity reflects complex human stories instead of just neat regional boundaries.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Daniel, you have grasped the main concept of the "Language Family Tree" very well! Your insight about proximity vs. relatedness highlights what Dr. McWhorter means when he says language history is about migration, not just geography. 

However, your essay is too short (221 words). While I appreciate your personal reflection, there needs to be more specific evidence to support your claims. For example, what specific examples from Dr. McWhorter's tour of the continents did you find most convincing? Also, how did you form your previous assumption that neighbors always speak related languages? Elaborating on these details will not only strengthen your argument but also help you easily meet the 300-word requirement.

Student Essay:
Language Families of the World Response
One part of Dr. McWorther’s lecture I found especially interesting was his
explanation of how language change is stagnated by literacy and printed literature. At
the 16:51 minute mark in Language Families of the World, Dr. McWorther discusses
how, historically, putting words to a page has cemented the way that a language has
been used, and having documented writing has restricted the organic nature in which a
language can evolve. While culturally and verbally, a language may change significantly,
these changes are not always reflected in literature because the manner in which things
have been written previously is considered the ‘correct’ way to use that language.
This phenomenon, while intriguing in its own right, prompted me to think about
how this manifests in other languages I am acquainted with, specifically American Sign
Language. In ASL, there is a written form called glossing, but from my understanding, it
is mostly an academic device, and does not have the same bearing on the signed version
of the language the way written English has on spoken English. While spoken English
may be held back by written English, ASL has easily and near-universally evolved as the
world around us has changed. To illustrate, the sign for phone, previously done with a
bulky cupped hand to mimic a corded or handheld phone, has transformed into a Y
handshape to symbolize a sleek smartphone. Almost all signers have casually
transitioned to this updated sign, signaling a subtle cultural change, one that would take
far longer to see the effects of in English, if ever achieved.
ASL can also evolve to meet the needs of a specific group of people, similar to the
way Black Country English evolved to meet the needs of the speakers, as noted at the
17:55 minute mark. Signs can be manufactured or changed for different environments,
based on what is most convenient. For example, in my home, the sign for ‘go’, instead of
a dual-finger pointing gesture, is done as a roll of both hands to make it easier for my
younger brother, who does not have the same fine motor control most signers would
have. ASL, which is not anchored down by formal writings, can freely change to meet
the needs of the many and the needs of the few, causing evolution to occur on a much
quicker timeline than spoken English.

Student Essay:
One topic Dr. John McWhorter discusses in 'Language Families of the World, Season 1, Episode 1' that I found especially interesting is the idea that sounds changing over long periods of time can later on develop into a new word used by the same or different language. (Time stamp: 7 minutes 25 seconds). In this part of the lecture, Dr. McWhorter explains that words are really just sequences of sounds, and over long periods of time, those sounds naturally shift as people speak more casually or slightly different. He uses the word "sock" as an example separately and clearly breaking it down into the sounds of  's' , 'ah' , and 'k'. According to McWhorter, a sound like 's' can slowly change depending on how it's pronounced. For example, it can soften into an 'sh' sound, similar to how someone might slur their words while tired or drunk. Over Generations that 'sh' sound can then shift even further into a 'zh' sound. These small pronunciation changes might seem unimportant in the moment, but over hundreds and thousands of years they can lead to words that sound completely different from the original. In McWhorter's example, the word "sock" might change from "sock", to "shawk" to "zhoo" and finally to "jue". 

I found this idea especially interesting because it shows how language change in unintentional and gradual, not something people plan or notice happening, it made me think about how often I change the way I pronounce words depending on who I'm talking to or how fast I'm speaking. For example, I might shorten words or pair sounds together without realizing it in everyday conversations, yet those tiny changes are exactly how languages evolve over time.

This concept also helped me understand how linguists are able to trace relationships between language families. Even when words look and sound very different today, recognizing sound changes makes it possible to see how languages are connected. Dr. McWhorter's explanation made language less fixed and more alive, shaped by every day speech happens everywhere and passed down across generations.
Teacher Feedback: Good job on this, Victor. You nicely summarized Dr. McWhorter's point on sound shift. For your next assignments, I'd like to see specific linguistic examples from your own experience. Additionally, please proofread for typos (e.g., "language change in unintentiaonl), capitalization (e.g., Over Generations), and phrasing.

Student Essay: What I found interesting and impressive was the explanation of sound change at the 7-minute 36-second mark. Specifically, Dr. John McWhorter showed that the sounds in the word "sock" can change when people pronounce it differently. One sound can transform into another. The sounds of "sock" are 's', 'ah', and 'k'. All three of these sounds can naturally transform into other sounds over time. For example, 's' can become 'sh', and then 'sh' can become 'zh'. Through these sound changes, a single word can be pronounced differently, creating a new language. Furthermore, the meaning of a word in one language can change in another. The first reason I found this impressive and interesting is that I learned for the first time the real reason why there are so many languages ​​in the world.  I now understand that they all originated from a single language, but over thousand years, due to changes in pronunciation, they evolved into more than 7,000 different languages we have today. The second reason is that I realized many words in my native language, Vietnamese, have similar meanings and pronunciations to words in English, French, and Chinese. I learned that due to historical invasions of Vietnam by these countries, many words from these languages ​​were adopted and pronounced differently by Vietnamese people, thus becoming part of the Vietnamese language. For example, the Vietnamese word for "safety" is "an toàn," which comes from the Chinese word "安全 - ānquán," also meaning safety. The Chinese character "quán" was pronounced as "toàn" by Vietnamese people, giving rise to the word "an toàn" in Vietnamese. Another example is the word "balcony" in English, which is "Balcon" in French.  With a different pronunciation, it becomes "Ban công" in Vietnamese. Although the pronunciations differ, these three words in the three languages ​​essentially have the same meaning. I had known these things for a long time while I was still in Vietnam, but I never paid them any attention.  It wasn't until I learned how one language evolved into so many different languages ​​that I realized my own language also has many connections and similarities with other languages.

Hi Gia, this is a fascinating reflection! Your specific examples in Vietnamese were excellent illustrations of how pronunciation adapts when languages interact. That being said, I just wanted to make a small distinction for you to keep in mind: the "sock" example illustrates language change over time, while your Vietnamese examples illustrate language change due to contact. Overall, excellent use of personal knowledge in your assignment!

Student Essay: What I found most intriguing about the documentary episode is when Dr. McWorther mentions the limits placed on the evolution of language by literacy and classist assumptions (Video 1, 17:00). I used to have a lisp, so I got that plenty after I got over my lisp, but it made me feel like I was worse at the language than I should be, when in actuality, it isn’t as important as people make it out to be. I also find this interesting because I’ve studied a lot of politics and classism and always had a light understanding of literacy being used as a barrier to entry for important class issues. For example, language and literacy were used throughout history to limit people's votes, such as the Three Estates in France or literacy tests in Jim Crow America. I think the connections between class and language are an interesting area of study, especially since literacy is often used by the rich to establish a level of dominance over poorer areas. The ideas presented in the video also backed this up, discussing the Black Country English dialect, in which there are many differences. The reason given for this is purely that the areas it developed in were slightly isolated and were poorer, and therefore didn’t have access to education and ‘proper’ literacy. I think that you can also see it in how racism predicates with the ideas of proper English, leading to people who may have separate dialects or not speak English as a first language being seen as improper or stupid. Overall, I just find the ideas of classism, politics, and language overlapping very interesting.
Teacher Feedback:

Your specific references to Jim Crow literacy tests and the Three Estates in France are outstanding examples of how "standard language" is often used to disenfranchise specific groups. 

For your next assignments, pay more attention to spelling (e.g., you misspelled the professor's name as "McWorther") and phrasing ("... how racism predicates with the ideas..." Here, you likely meant "intersects with" or "is predicated on.").

mentioned in Dr. McWhorter's talk, the sound change, which is a gradual change
of articulation over generations during the transferring generations of languages,

pronunciation of a sound, so from this accumulation of small phenomena under
longer spans of time, great contrasts among closely related languages may arise.
Sound change takes place evenly and predictably, usually without the knowledge
of those using the language. Failure to notice the tiny shifts over several
generations leads to languages, initially very similar, sounding increasingly
disparate. This is what Dr. McWhorter attempts to prove as to how linguists are
left with a clue justifying the similarities, and at the same time, different sound

Student Essay:
One topic that Dr. McWhorter discusses in Language Families of the World that I found especially intriguing is the idea that languages are constantly changing and diverging, even when speakers are not consciously trying to change them. This point comes up when Dr. McWhorter explains how languages within the same family gradually become distinct over time, eventually becoming mutually unintelligible. This discussion appears around Video 1, 12:30, when he explains how Latin slowly evolved into the Romance languages.

At this point in the film, Dr. McWhorter explains that languages do not suddenly split or change due to a single event. Instead, small pronunciation shifts, vocabulary changes, and grammatical differences accumulate across generations. Over time, these gradual changes result in entirely new languages, such as Spanish, French, Italian, and Portuguese, all of which descended from Latin. What stood out to me is his emphasis that language change is natural and unavoidable, not a sign that a language is “decaying” or becoming worse.

I find this idea interesting because many people, including myself at times, tend to think of language change as something negative or incorrect, especially when it comes to slang or informal speech. However, Dr. McWhorter’s explanation helped me realize that what we often label as “bad grammar” may simply be language in transition. For example, I have noticed differences between how older family members speak English compared to how people my age communicate, especially through texting and social media. Abbreviations, new slang, and altered sentence structures are common, and while they might seem improper to some, they reflect the same gradual processes Dr. McWhorter describes.

This concept also connects to my academic interests because it shows how language is deeply tied to culture, history, and human interaction. Understanding that languages naturally evolve makes it easier to appreciate linguistic diversity rather than judge it. Dr. McWhorter’s discussion helped me see languages not as fixed systems with rigid rules, but as living tools that adapt to the needs of their speakers over time.
Teacher Feedback:
Great job on this, Luke! You beautifully articulated the connection between the historical evolution of Latin and modern perceptions of "bad grammar." It also connects to the concepts of prescriptive vs. descriptive grammar :) 

My only minor suggestion for next time is to include specific examples of your experiences. For example, you can add a specific phrase you use that your older family members don't. 

Overall, nicely done!

Student Essay:
One topic I found intriguing comes up around 7:42, when Dr. McWorther discusses how sounds in words like "sock" change slightly from generation to generation. Over time, these small shifts can transform the way words are pronounced, as well as their meanings. He explains earlier, around 7:20, that each generation pronounces sounds a little differently, and after enough time, the transformation can be quite dramatic. I find this fascinating because I notice it in my own speech. For example, having grown up in New York City, Philadelphia, and New England, I often drop the "r" in words like "park" and "car," saying "pahk the cah," and I elongate vowels in words like "coffee" (cawfee) and "water" (wooder). Those around me who grew up in Florida, however, pronounce these words with clearer "r" sounds and shorter vowels. This demonstrates how regional influences shape pronunciation and how small differences reflect larger patterns in language evolution.

These differences make me wonder why English in America doesn't seem to be changing more rapidly, even though people from different regions pronounce words differently. Are these differences considered dialects, and if not, when would they become recognized as such? Dr. McWorther also discusses around 17:50 how literacy acts like a "stick in the wheel," slowing the natural evolution of language. If that is true, is it even possible for American English to change significantly? I also wonder how modern factors like the internet and ease of travel affect this. When scrolling through Instagram reels or TikTok, we are constantly exposed to different accents of English - will this eventually cause accents to merge into a more uniform, "standard," American accent? Similarly, exposure to television and movies could both preserve certain pronunciations while also encouraging new changes, meaning language change may not stop entirely, it may just take different forms. 

It is also interesting to compare this to other countries. During westward expansion, people traveled across America extensively, yet we do not see nearly as many English dialects/languages here as China has in its language. Dr. McWorther mentions around 9:18 how even certain English sounds, like the "aw" sound, are disappearing over time, which makes me wonder if the standardization of English in the U.S. is connected to education, media, and migration patterns. Student Essay: One topic that Dr. McWorther brings up that I find especially intriguing is how languages change. Another characteristic unique to the South is vowels being drawn out or changed. One common example is the word "oil". While this word is originally pronounced with two syllables, like "oy-yull", in the south it is common to hear it as one syllable, like "ull". For your future assignments, please watch your subject-verb agreement ("These southern characteristics...falls" should be "fall"). Also, try to be consistent with capitalization. You correctly capitalized 'the South' in your first paragraph, but later wrote 'in the south' in lowercase.

Student Essay:
One topic that Dr. McWhorter discusses in Language Families of the World that I found especially interesting is the idea that languages are always changing and that no language is more “advanced” or “primitive” than another. This comes up early in video 1, around 11 minutes, when he explains how languages naturally evolve over time through changes in pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary. To make this idea more concrete, he uses the word “sock” as an example, showing how its pronunciation has shifted gradually across generations without speakers being aware of it.

Dr. McWhorter explains that many people assume language change means that a language is getting worse or being used incorrectly. However, from a linguistic perspective, change is simply part of how language works. Languages are constantly adjusting, often becoming simpler in one area while becoming more complex in another. For instance, a language may lose certain word endings but depend more heavily on word order, or drop some verb forms while developing new supporting words. These kinds of changes do not indicate decline; they show that a language is continuing to develop.

This part of the film was especially meaningful to me because it connects to conversations I have heard throughout my life. Older family members often comment that people today “don’t speak correctly anymore,” especially when they hear slang or informal speech. Before watching this film, I tended to view these changes as negative. However, learning that even a basic word like “sock” once sounded different helped me realize that every generation speaks a slightly different version of the same language.

This topic also relates to my academic interests because it changes how I think about learning languages. Instead of seeing grammar rules as fixed and permanent, I now understand them as patterns that formed over time and may continue to shift. Viewing language this way makes it feel more natural and less rigid. Overall, this discussion helped me better understand why language change is normal and why it should be studied rather than criticized.

Hi Esther, this is a very clear and accurate summary of one of the course's most important themes. You correctly identified that languages don't "decay" or get "worse"; they simply trade complexity in one area for simplicity in another. For your future assignments, you can push for a slightly more critical voice. Instead of just summarizing the main points, try to apply them to a specific example of "bad" grammar you've heard recently to show why it's actually linguistically valid.

Student Essay:
Dr. McWorther surprised me many times in his discussion. To start, I am guilty of saying “rah fish” in my pronunciation rather than stressing the end of the true word, “raw,” in “raw fish.” My jaw dropped! What I found most intriguing about language was between minutes 12:30 and 13:29. He reflects on our own language, starting with the word “only.” The word we pronounce within it is “own,” which is used to describe just one thing. So, if a word within it already conveys this meaning, why is there an “ly” that follows it?

He then uses the word “forgive” as another example. We know its meaning is to no longer feel angry or resentful towards another, and we can utilize “give” in its pronunciation to convey this. But what is “for,” and why is it there? Because the sections we pronounce in our speech used to be prefixes from whole words. In modern usage, they now serve as added blubber to the word.

It was interesting because I never examined my own speech. What makes our word choices have their particular pronunciation, structure, and meaning? As a political science major, the evolution of language that “puffs up" connects to how politics and policy are often constructed. It takes an accumulation of people over time to shift how something is said. Whether words are shortened, elongated, or given new meanings, new material is applied as older vocabulary slowly withers away.

This principle can be compared to customary international law in my studies, which refers to laws people believe have always existed, even when they have not, due to normalized practice. What is astounding about the evolution of language is that there is no concrete rule declaring when words must shift in meaning or when sounds like “ly” or “for” are added. There are not always clear explanations we can derive, other than knowing these components must have meant something different at one point and now contribute to the full word.

In the same way, customary international law becomes respected and embedded without much thought because it is so commonly followed. For example, the norm against attacking fishing boats in international waters during times of political chaos. No formal international law initially declared this, but the practice became so natural that countries around the world respected it. Language operates in the same way. I do not think twice about pronouncing parts of words that no longer carry independent meaning because I have assumed, “well, it’s just like that.” This section opened up how I perceive language and its connection to my passion for political science.
Teacher Feedback: Hi Sofia, this is a great cross-disciplinary connection. Comparing language change to Customary International Law is a brilliant analogy. I also want to clarify the etymology you mentioned: "Only" actually comes from "one" + "ly," not "own." For your future assignments, please double-check the spelling of the professor's name. This is true to every culture since it reveals a collective fear: that somebody who you trusted the most has a secret life you never knew about.

The German movie succeeds by setting this struggle within the context of usual social circumstances: long-term relationships, married friends, civil dinner conversations, and allowing the dark side to disrupt the appearance. Ultimately, the film succeeds in any place since it is not based on a culture-specific problem but human weakness which remains the same, regardless of language, nation or civilization.

Student Essay:
The film Das perfekte Geheimnis (The Perfect Secret) touches on several themes that
transcend culture and language identity, especially when it comes to romantic relationships and
the expectations often placed on them. For instance, beginning at the 26:40 mark, the group
discusses the decision to have children and the role it plays in one’s life.
The argument made by Carlotta that kids are the best thing in life is quickly rebuffed by
Pepe, who feels that it’s absurd to think that a life without kids is senseless or without purpose.
Whether a couple decides to have children is often a personal choice that may depend on a
number of factors - including cultural and societal expectations. This is the case across a
disparate range of countries, cultures and language groups. The specific ideologies or
philosophies may differ from one group sharing a language, country or culture to another, but
the experience of considering conflicting, yet widely held views is common in many parts of the
world.
In the context of the Perfetti Gang debate, it is briefly discussed whether bringing a new
life into the world is selfish. Bianca suggests that having a child is for the betterment of the
world: a child is born full of potential to solve problems currently plaguing the world. On the
other hand, it can be self-serving for parents to have children out of a fear of getting older, an
idea that Eva poses. In the United States and other Western countries, environmental concerns
have given momentum to a movement of voluntary childlessness, giving way to the idea that
continuing the human population is selfish and not in the best interest of the planet.
Simultaneously, in the same countries exist “pronatalist” movements, which promote
increasing the falling birthrate, and deem childlessness as selfish and against human interests.
This example shows that the actual reasons why some would see having or not having children
as selfish may differ from place to place – in this case Germany and the United States – but
similar arguments are made in each case. In this way, the film demonstrates that many couples
face similar considerations across the globe when planning a future together.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Alexis, great job on this. You not only correctly identified the film's presentation but also beautifully connected it to modern environmental concerns, which demonstrates your deep understanding of why this theme is universal.
While your analysis of the argument between Carlotta and Pepe is accurate, it's worth noting Pepe's background (e.g., his being a closeted gay man in a heteronormative group), as it adds a layer to your analysis.
Lastly, your submission file contained annotations. For your next assignment, please ensure you submit a clean final version without these markup elements.

Student Essay:
The reason The Perfect Secret works so well across so many cultures is because the main idea of
the film is something almost everyone can relate to, that is that people keep secrets, even from
the people they love the most. The film explores secrecy, trust, jealousy, and the gap between
how people present themselves publicly and who they really are privately. These dynamics exist
in virtually every society, regardless of language, religion, or social norms. While the details on
culture may change, the emotional structure of relationships remains similar worldwide. You can
see that relationships everywhere are built on trust, but they are also full of things left unsaid,
which is exactly what the film displays.
One major reason the theme translates so well is the role of smartphones. No matter the culture,
phones have become deeply personal objects. They hold private conversations, emotional
connections, and sometimes secrets that partners or friends don’t know about; I can even vouch
for this. The idea of being forced to share everything on your phone instantly creates tension
because almost everyone has something they wouldn’t want to reveal in front of others. That
discomfort doesn’t depend on language or culture, it’s a shared experience.
A scene that feels especially true to real life relationships happens when the dinner guests agree
to the phone game and messages begin revealing hidden romantic tension. In the German
version, this moment comes up around video 2 at about the 32 minute mark. A message with
flirting undertones is exposed, and suddenly the mood at the table changes. What stood out to me
is that the issue isn’t outright cheating, but emotional secrecy. This reflects real relationships,
where jealousy often comes from what might be happening rather than what has already
happened. Many couples struggle with defining emotional boundaries, and this scene captures
that gray area perfectly.
What makes this moment so relatable is how quickly trust starts to unravel. The characters
become defensive, suspicious, and uncomfortable, which mirrors how people react in real life
when they feel exposed or threatened. The film shows that even small secrets can feel huge once
they’re brought into the open.
Overall, The Perfect Secret works across cultures because it’s about human behavior. Fear of
judgment, the want for self privacy, and jealousy in relationships are things people experience
everywhere, which is why the story continues to resonate worldwide and why I can relate to it.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Isaiah, your argument that the film works globally because it explores the "gray area" of relationships is excellent. You correctly identify that the tension often comes not from the act itself, but from the ambiguity of digital communication. 

However, your evidence is a bit vague. You mention a scene where a "message with flirting undertones is exposed." Which message? Who received it? With specifics, your analysis of the "gray area" would have been grounded in concrete proof. 

Overall, great job!

Student Essay:

And because everyone owns a phone and uses it privately, the movie’s message immediately seems so relatable across cultures.

I think most of the movie can relate to or apply to most relationships, as it revolves around people discovering things that were kept from them. This situation starts at approximately 18:57 in video 1, when Rocco’s wife says that everyone is claiming they don’t have secrets, and everybody agrees. and continues until the end of the second video and the start of the third, with everyone discovering each other’s deepest secrets. This moment deeply reflects how each individual behaves: publicly claiming honesty while privately fearing that their secret will be exposed. The tension of the exposure continues throughout the movie, challenging the trust and good relationships within the group.

The movie fits so well for every type of relationship, and culture, because it all has the same base - a deep, private secret that shouldn’t be exposed. And it also shows that any relationship is based on “trust,” which, in reality, is just an assumption rather than real transparency. This example shows how the issue that arises in the movie can be applied to all types of relationships.

Ultimately, the movie Perfect Secret resonates across different cultures because it highlights a universal human trait: relationships will often rely only on selective honesty, and by forcing hidden realities into the open, the movie shows how easily trust and the relationship can be fractured.

Hi Valeriia, you've constructed a strong argument that relationships often rely on selective honesty and that trust is frequently just a fragile assumption. Your connection between the universality of the film and the ubiquity of smartphones is also excellent. 

However, your analysis of the second scene (Video 2, 33:41) should have been more accurately described. You used this scene to argue that a "deep, private secret" was being exposed. However, Leo was mistaken for being gay because he was holding Pepe's phone; his "secret" wasn't actually revealed, but rather, a misunderstanding occurred. Hi Angelina, you've done a good job identifying the illusion of intimacy as the film's central point. Your observation that the characters thought they knew everything about each other, only to realize they were actually strangers, is a strong point. 

However, I have a few suggestions for improvement. First, your opening two sentences are repetitive; I recommend combining them into one concise statement. Student Essay:
The Perfect Secret, the German adaptation of the Italian film Perfetti Sconosciuti, has achieved international success, with the original story translated into more than 18 languages worldwide today. I believe the reason why this film resonates with audiences globally is that it focuses on the universal human experience rather than culturally specific traditions. The film explores so many different facets of human social interactions: relationships, romance, and family, with situations that are universally accepted. The director worked very hard to ensure that the film had a wide range of widely accepted social interactions. The character development is very strong in this film. Instead of focusing on a single story, the director sheds light on each individual in the group. By doing so, it allows audiences from all different cultural backgrounds to recognize themselves in the characters.

A particularly relatable scene occurs very early in the film at 2 minutes and 19 seconds, when the teenage daughter ignores her mother while focusing on her electronic device. This interaction is very typical among teenagers in Western cultures, particularly in the United States. In the United States, adolescents often begin questioning authority as teenagers. Many teenagers become very involved in their social lives, and this scene represents that well across cultures. An even deeper dynamic here is how the mother felt after this interaction; it's a pretty universal feeling that I'm sure parents of all different cultural backgrounds have felt.

Another scene that resonates with cultures universally is at 20 minutes 6 seconds in the second video, when the topic of dating and past relationships is drawn into the mix. A character receives a call from her ex-boyfriend during dinner; he is only seeking advice about his new relationship, but her current boyfriend is still not happy. This creates tension because the current boyfriend did not know that they were still in contact with each other. This moment captures a universally accepted dilemma: how past relationships can influence dating life.

Overall, I think the film truly serves the public well, and that by watching it, you begin to feel how similar we are rather than different (I think this is a strong underlying theme in the film). It made the film feel very real at times, and often I forgot I was even watching an international film, especially one set over 5000 miles from Florida.
Teacher Feedback: Hi Daniel, this is a very strong essay. You've successfully identified the teenager's conflict with the parents as a key point of universality. Your analysis of the ex-boyfried call is also solid. Mechanically, you tend to repeat the phrase "universally accepted" or "widely accepted." Conflict isn't really "accepted"; it is "experienced" or "recognized." A better phrase would be "situations that are univesally recognizable."

Teacher Feedback:
Hi Caleb, you correctly identified the film's reliance on dramatic conflict to drive the plot.

However, your argument relies on overgeneralizations. You stated that "everyone in the movie is a cheater" and implied this reflects the real world. Does everyone actually cheat? Rather than stating this as a fact, you should engage more deeply with your opinion: Is the film exaggerating to make a point, or is it exposing a hidden reality? Furthermore, regarding the dramatic element you analyzed, you did a good job describing the conflict. However, you didn't explain how that drama contributes to the film's universality. 

Finally, try to elevate your tone in future assignments; phrases like "Bianca was a little dumb" are too informal for academic writing.

Student Essay: After watching The Perfect Secret, one of the main themes that I feel carries over across cultures is that nothing stays a secret forever. They all try to bluff and avoid answering their phone at one point or try to avoid explaining the call/text/image they got but it never ends up working well for them. I think this is a perfect reflection of a lesson that most people within society could stand to learn. Keeping secrets from loved ones, be that friends, family, or partners, will never end up going the way you want it to. Also, in this movie multiple of the characters are cheating on. their partner, which I can never find an excuse for. Relationships of any kind, especially romantic ones, are built upon trust, putting your trust in someone in various scenarios, and letting them see you at your worst is one of the key components of a relationship. So when a person cheats, they are willingly going against everything that makes a relationship meaningful in a way that only serves to benefit them. A lot of cheaters will use the excuse that they didn't want to hurt the feelings of the person they were in a relationship with, when in actuality it is often because they are too emotionally immature to handle the emotions of another person and face them.

Hi Shianne, 

You did a good job elaborating on your main argument regarding the movie's content. 

However, the essay reads more like a general opinion on the morality of cheating than a close analysis of the film. You did not reference a specific scene with a timestamp. You need to ground your arguments in concrete evidence (e.g., specific examples from real-world situations connected to the particular movie scene).

Student Essay: When I think about relationships, whether it be romantic or just platonic, I think about someone that is your ride or die, no matter what. Someone you never want to live your life without, and someone that can help support you with your shortcomings, and vice versa. I think that Pepe exhibits this line of thought in a perfect way in Perfect Secret. In the second video, at 3:10, Pepe is telling the story of how humans came to be. He says that people used to have round torsos, 2 heads, and 4 hands and feet. He says that Zeus, the ancient Greek God, wanted to weaken the people, so he cut them into two halves, resulting in what we look like today. Pepe goes on to finish the story by talking about how "all our lives, we seek our other half that was violently torn from us," (3:25). This story I feel is a great example of how love and relationships really do not change, no matter the culture or time period, since it is a story by Plato from presumably thousands of years ago. A relationship is very much like that of a single organism that has 2 heads and 4 arms and legs, in the sense that you are always working towards the same goals (relatively), and you act as a tandem. Furthermore, I think the second point in the original story, about searching for our partner our whole lives, also rings true. When people are looking for a close relationship, they want someone who is their "other half," in a sense. They want someone who has their best interests in mind, who makes up for their faults, and who unconditionally loves them. Plato and Pepe both demonstrate that love and relationships do not change much across cultures, in two wildly different time periods.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Levi, 

You selected a beautiful and highly relevant scene to analyze. Your argument that this ancient Greek story proves the timeless, cross-cultural nature of the search for a soulmate is excellent. 

To take this analysis further, consider the irony of the scene. Pepe tells this story about wholeness, but he is hiding his true self and his other half from his friends at the same time. Additionally, the people at the table want to believe they have found their other halves, but the game shows they do not fully know their partners. The myth highlights the ideal, while the movie exposes the messy reality. Mentioning this contrast would have added significant depth to your essay.

Student Essay: The film The Perfect Secret tells the story of a group of friends that one night at dinner decide to play a game, that would soon reveal all of their secrets to each other. The film focuses on the theme that everyone has secrets, and that no matter how close people are to each other, they may be hiding something. The friends would soon find out that they do not know each other as well as they thought they did. Notifications, messages, and phone calls expose their lies, infidelity, and deepest secrets, creating tension and conflict among both romantic partners and longtime friends. The film is entertaining and easy to watch, it leaves the viewer craving more, trying to figure out whose secret is going to be exposed next, the producers were also clever to include some hints throughout the movie through dialogue, facial expressions, and actions, which makes the viewer also have to read between the lines. No matter where you are from, what language you speak, or your culture, the film speaks to you. It is relatable, it is captivating. The reason why the film has such universal applicability is because everyone can relate. As humans, we crave interaction, thrive in communities and groupa, we have the need to create bonds and relationships. However, as humans we also have many flaws, and therefore our relationships have many flaws too. We can know a person for years, yet not really know her. That is what the film depicts, it shows what we already know, that people have secrets, that people are always hiding something, that there is no way you can truly know someone. However, the film does it in an open way, in a way that leaves us wondering, what’s next? Something that is true for all relationship romantic or not is the shock of finding out someone is not who they appear to be, an example of that in the film is when they thought simon was having an affair with Hannes (video 2 31:55-32:45). This scene can represent what people feel when they discover another’s lies or secrets whether it is in a romantic relationship or a friendship-- the hurt, the confusion, the questioning.  The answer as to why the film has universal applicability lies within our nature. Human nature drives us to seek love, connection, and understanding, while at the same time protecting ourselves from judgment and vulnerability by hiding parts of who we are. This tension between closeness and secrecy is what shapes so many relationships, and it is exactly what the film exposes, making its story relatable, as the emotional conflict is human, not cultural.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Brunna, 

You have a strong grasp of the film's central theme, and your analysis of human nature as the driver of the film's universal appeal is insightful. 

However, you confused Simon with Leo. In the scene you referenced, the group suspects Leo is having an affair with a man. Accurate character identification is essential. 

Additionally, watch out for grammar and typos. You have several run-on sentences and typos. 

Overall, great work!

Student Essay:
At the beginning of the film, the audience is introduced to a close-knit group of friends who share
a strong bond. The group of boys were having a good time in nature without the impact/pressure of any
modern technology. As the film progresses, the viewers are introduced to the character’s personal lives,
which initially appear to be stable and ideal. Beneath the surface it becomes evident that each character is

character Leo admits that being a stay-at-home father is not as enjoyable as he portrays on Instagram.
Many people regardless of culture or age have the same desire to create this ideal life online.
A scene that shows the film’s relevance to all relationships occurs near the end, when Carlotta
breaks down and reveals that she does not want to be a working mother but instead would prefer staying
at home with her children (Video 3 at 20 seconds). The husband Leo had already explained that he would
prefer to return to work rather than staying at home and taking care of the children. Because neither
Carlotta or Leo properly communicates these feeling, resentment quickly builds. This lack of
communication ultimately led to serious consequences for their marriage. Some of these consequences
included infidelity and substance abuse. When people fail to communicate their needs and emotions, they
risk feeling unseen and misunderstood. Over time, these unmet needs can foster resentment and emotional
distance.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Mila, 

You provided a clear central focus on the universality of hidden struggles, and your analysis of Leo and Carlotta's conflict regarding parenting roles effectively connects these themes to the broader pressure of social media. 

However, your essay is just under the minimum word count (298 words). Because of this brevity, the conclusion feels slightly rushed. To strengthen your argument, you could have expanded on the consequences you mentioned. 

Additionally, please review your grammar (see the comments attached to your submission). 

Overall, great work!

Student Essay:
The theme of The Perfect sense has reached many different cultural audiences because it focuses on shared human experiences. The film shows complexities behind people’s honesty and privacy. In most cultures, friendships and romantic relationships are built on trust, yet trust does not always mean complete transparency. Most people are still self-preserving in the sense of protecting themselves, avoiding conflict, and maintaining their image. These choices are not distinct to one culture, which explains how the film has reached global success and various adaptations.  

 

The film focuses on the central phone game. With using phones as the main focal point, individuals all over the world can relate to the shared use of a phone and the implications that may come with it. Phones are deeply personal objects world-wide that contain private conversations and personal memories many would not want to be shared. Although cultures have differing views on privacy, the fear of one’s life being personally exploited would is a common fear felt across most phone users. The film showcases this fear and the lengths that people would go to not have that fear get the best of them. Some going to drastic lengths to maintain that perfect facade, while some accept their exposed reality.  

 

For example, at 16:34 in the second clip of the movie, Simon reads a message from Bianca’s ex, which leads him to accuse Bianca of secretly still sleeping with her ex. Afterwards, to prove her innocence, Bianca calls him to make clear that they are only in contact to help her ex talk to women. This quarrel demonstrates a common fear that many couples no matter the culture: the fear of one not being good enough for their partner, causing one to cheat. Cheating scandals happen across the globe, and many couples have had to deal with the situation of being accused and clearing up their name like Bianca, or in Simon’s case, being accused and proven guilty.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Jana,

You did a good job providing a solid analysis of the Bianca/Simon dynamic, correctly noting that jealousy often stems from a feeling of inadequacy. Your analysis of the Bianca/Simon scene is good, but you ended abruptly by saying Simon was "proven guilty" without explaining what he was guilty of (impregnating another woman). A quick clarification there would have solidified your point about the difference between Bianca's "innocent" secret and Simon's "guilty" one.

Also, you referred to the film as "The Perfect Sense," which is a completely different movie; the correct title is The Perfect Secret.

Lastly, please pay attention to grammar and wording next time. Your phrasing is often confusing. For example, your sentence regarding "the fear of one's life being personally exploited" is difficult to follow due to grammatical errors ("would is") and vague vocabulary. In the future, focus on refining your sentences to ensure your argument is clear and easy to read.

Overall, good work!

However, your analysis needs to be much more specific to the film itself. Student Essay:

Student Essay:

Student Essay:
The German adaptation of Perfetti Sconosciuti, an Italian film, is Perfect Stranger, where a simple dinner party escalates quickly. The film is simple yet contains a theme that is prominent due to its relevance. When the seven friends place their cell phones in the center of the dinner table, they exchange their calls and texts to the group to attest loyalty in both their romantic relationships and friendships. 

The theme of the German film is a negative representation of modern society’s method of communication, where hiding their lives behind a screen is preferred to sharing intimate information personally to close ones- which may compromise many’s own relationships. 

An example in the film, Perfect Stranger, of the theme is when Pepe conceals he is gay from the group. Instead of bringing his romantic partner, he decides to hide it. When Pepe finally reveals this secret that he has been hiding, the theme is expressed. The scene is a representation of the discomfort often experienced when our choices are revealed and judged. 

Pepe is a prime example of hiding behind a screen instead of expressing himself to his closest friends. At approximately 2 minutes and 50 seconds into the third video, Pepe finally reveals that he is the one that is the true homosexual in the group of friends and lovers. Rather than being honest, concealing the secret introduced a lot of conflict between multiple people. Once Pepe decided to tell the dinner party the truth, they all embraced him for what he was rather than kicking him out of the group for his preferences. If Pepe had informed the group his true situation, the friends and their partners would have not only reduced more future conflict, but they would have also accepted Pepe sooner. Pepe most likely hid this for the duration of the film due to the fear of being criticized. This is an accurate representation of people’s expressions being hindered due to poor communication we experience with the influence of social media and phones.

In conclusion, Perfect Stranger is an accurate adaptation of smartphones' effect on modern communication. The film introduces the idea that people should be more comfortable in sharing information about themselves to those who are closest rather than hiding behind lies or smartphones. Less problematic communication may result with more directness.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Ryan, you've correctly identified the fear of judgment as the universal engine driving this film. 

However, regarding the title of the film, you refer to it as "Perfect Stranger." While the original Italian film is called Perfetti Sconosciuti ("Perfect Strangers"), the German adaptation you watched is titled The Perfect Secret.

Additionally, your interpretation that the friends "accepted Pepe sooner" and "all embraced him" does not capture the full tension. In the film, some friends (like the taxi driver) struggle with deep-seated homophobia before coming around. 

Lastly, double-check for phrasing like "...compromise many's own relationships." It is better to write "many people's relationships."

Student Essay:
After watching the movie Perfect Secret, I came to the conclusion that the overall theme of
the film was the universal tendency to hide secrets from society, even when that secrecy extends
to one’s closest friends or romantic partners. The widespread adaptability of the film across

smartphones of the characters function almost as containers for desires and decisions that they

When flirtatious and intimate messages with third parties are exposed, such as the one between
Leo and Hannes (Video 2 at 32 minutes and 30 seconds), the result shows a truth that applies
broadly to many people. Trust in relationships is often built on partial knowledge rather than

conflicts across all cultures. Furthermore, the dynamic among this group of friends illustrates

raises the question of whether total transparency is even desirable or sustainable in the first place.

context.

friends have each other's backs no matter the situation.
Overall, the film “Perfect Secret” shows that simple settings can explore universal truths
about relationships. Through the dinner-table game and the revelations in scenes with
Carlotta and Leo, the film highlights trust, secrecy, and loyalty in both friendships and
romantic partnerships. These experiences are relatable across cultures, which is why
the story has been adapted into so many languages. The film demonstrates that,
despite cultural differences, the complexities of human relationships are truly universal.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Kseniya, great job analyzing the film's gender dynamics. Your point about Carlotta was excellent: the universality here is that female friendships often involve a level of disclosure that men find shocking. 

However, you need to be much more concise. You exceeded the maximum word count by a wide margin. You have two introductory paragraphs that say essentially the same thing. You could combine these into one. 

Additionally, please proofread for phrasing and punctuation. In terms of phrasing, for example, you wrote "Carlotta gets a call from her childhood...." You likely meant "from her childhood friend." For punctuation, watch your commas. "However that soon backfires..." needs a comma after "However."

Student Essay: In the movie Perfect Secret, at 17:40 of part two, the scene where Simon sees a text from Bianca’s ex mentioning wanting to have sex causes him to immediately lose trust. This shows  a common dynamic in relationships, the fragility of trust, and how easily it can be lost, and the impact of perceived betrayal. Trust is the foundation of any healthy relationship, and once it is shaken, even by something as seemingly small as a message, it can trigger doubt, insecurity, and emotional distance. Which drags down tons of relationships these days. In this scene, Simon’s reaction is not just about the text itself but what it symbolizes: the fear that his partner might have lingering feelings for another guy or secrets. This fear resonates with many people because relationships that go the distance inherently involve vulnerability. When one partner encounters a potential threat, it can provoke a loss of confidence in the bond they share which can cause a downward spiral at least for one person. This theme is universal because human relationships rely on mutual honesty and transparency. Misunderstandings, assumptions, and external influences, such as past relationships or social media, often cause issues, but how they handle them is what makes or breaks them. Many couples experience moments when one partner misinterprets an action, a message, or even a gesture, leading to temporary distrust, if not that, frustration. If these moments are not addressed with open communication and empathy, they can escalate into larger conflicts or turn into things that had nothing to do with the original issue. The scene in Perfect Secret reflects this pattern: Simon’s immediate doubt shows how quickly trust can be ruined without a conversation.. The scene emphasizes that trust must be dealt with continuously. It also proves that insecurity, jealousy, and past experiences are common challenges in relationships. While the scenario is specific to Simon and Bianca, it mirrors real-life situations where couples must navigate misunderstandings and fears to strengthen their connection. The universality of this theme lies in its reflection of human emotion—the delicate balance between love and trust that all relationships must maintain.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Luke, 

You provided a relatable analysis of how quickly trust can erode. Your observation that trust is often built on "partial knowledge" is insightful. 

To strengthen your essay, try to engage more deeply with the Simon/Bainca dynamic. While Bianca was indeed communicating with her ex, the text itself was likely not as explicit as you described. Analyzing how they communicate and why Simon feels threatened even by non-sexual contact would add significant depth to your analysis. 

Finally, please focus on proofreading for grammar and mechanics. You had a few sentence fragments (e.g., "Which drags down...") and some informal phrasing (e.g., "tons of"). 

Overall, good work!

Student Essay:

Teacher Feedback:
Hi Victor, 

You correctly identified the film's universal themes of vulnerability and the fear of judgment. Your observation that "assumption can be false" even among long-term friends is a strong point. 

However, your essay is very generic. You did not name a single character (e.g., Rocco, Eva) or describe a specific plot point in detail. Student Essay:

In the beginning of the game, Bianca and Simon seems such a lovely couple, but

Hi Jayce, 

You provided a good overview of the three main conflicts. Your observation that the film is about "managing boundaries" rather than total transparency is a strong point. 

However, your essay has several idiom errors that impact clarity. Overall, good work!

Student Essay:

Hiding of things as basic as therapy or old cigarette ad campaigns sparks discussions about how people place ideas at different levels of importance. Most people don’t bat an eye at therapy, but we’re shown multiple times Rocco getting defensive about the ineffectiveness of therapy.

This idea is expanded upon later in a much larger scene when Pepe decides to come out to the group (Video 2 at 33 min and 46 seconds), where all the characters discuss their opinions on Pepe’s choice to hide his identity. Hi David, 

You provided a solid analysis of the film's central theme, and your point about the difficulty of transferring LGBTQ themes across cultures is particularly insightful. 

However, your essay has some timeline and character confusion. You cited Video 2 (23:46) as the moment Pepe comes out; while the characters are talking about being gay at that moment, Pepe actually admits the truth and officially comes out later, in Video 3 (minutes 4-5). Additionally, be careful with character dynamics. Simon is the one disgusted by the "sleeping in the same bed" memory, not Leo. 

Overall, good work! 

+ For grammar, please pay attention to the use of prepositions (e.g., "...big secret of him being gay" should be "...big secret about his being gay.") and wording (e.g., "truth" instead of "true-all.").

Student Essay:

Student Essay:
The movie "The Perfect Secret" has adapted into so many different languages, which shows how relatable its message is to people everywhere around the world. The reason behind why it works in so many cultures is that it deals with everyday experiences people face, like privacy, trust, and secrets in friendships or romantic relationships. Even though people live in different places and have different traditions, almost everybody uses some sort of technology to communicate and keep private information. Because of this, the conflicts in the film about personal space, honesty, and boundaries feel very relatable to people, especially as society changes and promotes the use of technology.  

   Throughout the film, the game shows how much people actually depend on their phones and how risky it might be when that private information is revealed to their closest ones. The characters in this movie think they know each other very well, but once calls and messages start appearing, many secrets come out, and tension starts to quickly build up. The film shows that privacy doesn't always mean someone is lying. Sometimes it means they want to keep their private matters to themselves. People all around the world deal with the same struggle of trying to be honest, while also needing personal space. 

   A scene that shows why this theme relates to everyone is in video 2 at 12 minutes and 30 seconds. In this scene, Pepe gets upset when the group pressures Leo to answer a text. Student Essay:
The German film Das perfekte Geheimnis or The Perfect Secret works effectively across cultures because it focuses on universal dynamics of human relationships: secrecy, trust, social pressure, and the fear of being judged, rather than culture specific dynamics. In this film, secrecy is treated as both normal and dangerous in relationships. This theme first appears in clip 1 at 17:35, when Eva asks, "How many couples would it ruin if one looked through the other's phone?" While the question she presents is important, what stands out is how uncomfortable each guest becomes as Eva frames secrecy as an assumed part of intimacy. A few minutes later, at 18:56, Eva pushes further by saying, "So you're all claiming to have no secrets?" Secrecy functions as a protective mechanism. Across cultures, people withhold information not necessarily out of hate or bitterness, but out of fear of conflict, rejection, or loss of control. The phone simply places these details in one, tangible place, making the tension visible.

Social pressure further explains why characters choose secrecy over honesty. Around 33-34 minutes in clip 1, Leo expresses resentment toward paternity leave and describes feeling forced to conform in order to be accepted. This pressure becomes more apparent later at 13:20 in clip 2, when he exclaims, "These damn [phones] are ruining us. They rob us of our privacy!" His defensiveness shows his anxiety about failing to meet social expectations. Although the specifics of gender roles and success differ by culture, the fear of judgement and exclusion is nearly universal. 

The film also explores why people often communicate indirectly by sharing grievances with others instead of addressing issues directly. Near 42 minutes in clip 1, Carlotta's friend calls, discussing Carlotta's intimate life, revealing private information about her and Leo. A similar patterns appears around 18:20 in clip 2, when Matti asks Bianca if her therapist friend (Eva) is still being "b----y." These moments show how indirect communication allows people to release frustration without confronting uncomfortable situations. However, the film shows that this behavior often leads to feelings of betrayal when secrets rise to the surface. This dynamic is widely relatable because it shows a common theme: people participate in private communication while expecting loyalty and discretion from others.

For your next assignment, please do a quick grammar check before submitting; you had some small errors ("A similar patterns appears" "...Carlotta's intimate life, and revealing private..."). 

Overall, great job!
