Student Essay:
One reason The Perfect Secret has been adapted so widely across cultures is that it focuses on relationship issues that most people recognize in their own lives. No matter where someone lives, close relationships involve a balance between honesty and privacy. The film shows how easily that balance can be disrupted when private communication becomes public, revealing emotions and insecurities that exist in many friendships and romantic relationships around the world.

A scene that clearly reflects this universality occurs when the group decides to place their phones on the table and agree to share every message and call that comes in (around 34–36 minutes into the film). What stands out in this moment is how casual the decision initially seems. Several characters laugh or make jokes, suggesting confidence in their relationships. This reaction feels familiar, as many people believe trust exists simply because major conflicts have not yet surfaced.

As the game unfolds, however, the tension becomes obvious. Even messages that are not serious or romantic cause discomfort between partners. For example, a seemingly harmless text from a coworker creates suspicion and defensiveness, showing how easily trust can be shaken when context is removed. This situation applies to many real-life relationships, where partners may not be hiding betrayal but still worry about how certain interactions might be perceived. The fear is not always about guilt, but about being misunderstood.

The scene also affects the group’s friendships. Conversations become awkward, humor feels forced, and the mood shifts noticeably as personal information is exposed. This reflects how friendships often rely on unspoken limits. People may care deeply for one another while still choosing not to share everything. When those boundaries disappear, relationships are tested in uncomfortable ways.

What makes this theme work across cultures is that it does not depend on specific traditions or values. Instead, it highlights shared human emotions—vulnerability, fear of judgment, and the desire to protect oneself. The Perfect Secret ultimately suggests that complete transparency is not always necessary for strong relationships. In many cases, understanding and discretion are what allow both romantic relationships and friendships to endure.

Great job on this. Your observation that "trust exists simply because major conflicts have not yet surfaced" is a profound psychological insight.

Additionally, your timestamp for the start of the game is incorrect. The game actually begins much earlier, around 19:21 in Video 1 (the "Coming Clean" scene). The segment you cited actually covers the conversation about the difficulties of being a stay-at-home dad and Bianca's inheritance. For future assignments, please ensure you ground your analysis in concrete evidence with accurate timestamps.

This scene establishes that Martin's depression is affecting all areas of his life.

A strong contrast happens later in the movie during the early stages of the alcohol experiment. Before entering his classroom, Martin tests his BAC (blood alcohol content) and reveals he is at a .047. Reflecting on what his group discussed, he is eager to see the effects. The camera then opens up to the classroom at around 1:03 in the second video, with Martin's demeanor toward his students changed. In the scene, Martin is much more relaxed, engaging with his students, and confident! He explains the lesson using an effective election metaphor, which gets many more students involved in the material.

The insight that allows Martin to grow is the realization that alcohol was never the true source of his confidence or his happiness. While the drinking lowered his anxiety and allowed him to reconnect to teaching, it created a nasty product in the end. The experiment revealed that all the qualities Martin thought he had lost were still inside him this whole time. By the end of the film, Martin realizes that real growth happens when you're actively engaged in life rather than escaping from it.

Excellent work.

Student Essay:
The movie Another Round initially flirts with the idea that alcohol can help unlock a better version on oneself, the film gradually warps that fantasy into revealing the dark reality that alcohol can bring through Martin’s emotional arc. His carefree and expressive movements show that he is now willing to engage with life instead of observing it from a distance.  

This insight that Martin gains does not come from altering oneself with the crutch of alcohol, but from embracing risk, connection, and emotional honesty. Throughout the movie, Martin relies on alcohol to hone in on these qualities; at the beginning of group testing their theories, it showed how alcohol positively affected their moods and attention spans. However, the continued use of alcohol exposed how fragile and dangerous avoiding one’s problems can be when using alcohol to escape from reality. The death of Tommy underscores this reality, showcasing how alcohol can intensify despair instead of curing it.

despite the funeral that just happened. Even though alcohol is still present, the focus of the scene
is not just on drinking but on Martin reconnecting his students. This emotion change is a huge
contrast to everything that was happening beforehand.
The insight Martin gains is that alcohol itself is not the solution to his unhappiness. At
first, he believes that drinking will make him a better teacher, husband, and friend. Over time he
realizes that it only temporarily hides his problems and can deepen his depression, as seen in the
death of his friend Tommy. His growth comes from accepting uncertainty and allowing himself
to feel joy again without depending on alcohol as a crutch.
I believe the final message of the movie seems to be that life should be lived with
openness and courage. Happiness does not come from constant control or from numbing pain
with substances. Instead, it comes from hanging out with friends, doing things you love and
enjoy, and being present in the moment.
Teacher Feedback:

You selected a compelling scene to illustrate the consequences of Martin's drinking.

Overall, great job!

Student Essay:

Student Essay:
The film, Another Round, depicts a group of teachers who are friends that decide to
partake in a drinking experiment to test a theory. As they undergo the experiment, they test
the limits of their abilities to handle such frequent drinking at high amounts. Through the
storyline the themes of substance abuse, depression, death, and finding contentment are
addressed.
The main character, Martin, is introduced as someone who’s life is underwhelming.
The lack of joy in his day-to-day experiences affects different realms of his life, including
occupational, romantic, and social. As Martin is leaving to go to Nikolaj’s birthday dinner,
he looks at his children who seem disinterested that he is leaving and focus only on the TV
(Video 1, 11 min 12 seconds). This reaction and the one he had from his wife when he
asked if she found him boring both discourage him and make him feel insignificant (Video
1, 6 min 35 seconds).
After hearing from his friend that there is a theory that humans are born with a
0.05% BAC deficiency and that drinking to reach and maintain this level could increase
creativity and relax an individual, he decides to try it at work. The positive effect it had on
Martin can be seen while he teaches his students about Roosevelt, Churchill, and Hitler,
and does so through an interactive method that the students have a great reaction to
(Video 2, 3 min 28 seconds).
However, while it seemed to improve their quality of life for a period, the drinking
began to do more damage than good. They eventually conclude the experiment on the
claims that it had severe negative effects and made them prone to alcoholism. This alludes
to the message of the movie that humans cannot rely on any one thing to be their source of
joy in life. One should look for it in all their experiences, even mundane ones. At the end of
the movie, the group of men have drinks with their students, but it is not in attempt to get
through the day, instead it is in addition to their celebrations and festivities. As for Martin,

Teacher Feedback:
Hi Sophie, 

This is a very strong essay. You did an excellent job establishing Martin's initial isolation. I also really appreciated your distinction in the conclusion that, at the end, the alcohol is "in addition to their celebration" rather than a tool to get through the day." 

To make your essay even stronger, include the final dance in your analysis. You mention "relishing" life, and Martin's dance at the harbor is the physical embodiment of that idea. 

Lastly, please proofread for grammar (see the attached comments on your submission). 

Overall, great job!

Student Essay: The film Another Round portrays various attitudes towards life and living, which affect the main character, Martin, and his colleagues. Student Essay: Despite the film, Another Round, initial positive view on alcohol, the perspective shifts as the characters' lives are affected. The theme demonstrates a stark contrast as the film progresses. This is evident for Martin, where he is initially depressed in both settings- his school job and at home with his wife. 6 minutes and 37 seconds into the film, Martin asks his wife whether she finds him boring or not. Then, Anika reveals that he is dissimilar to the “old-version” when he was younger. This observation is a reflection of his disinterest in everyday life events. Teacher Feedback:
Hi Ryan, 

You selected two excellent scenes to contrast Martin's life. This effectively demonstrates how the alcohol initially repaired his relationship with Anika. 

However, you argue for "moderation," but you didn't mention Martin's final dance. In that scene, he is letting go of control entirely while drinking alcohol. Discussing why he chooses to drink and dance at the end is crucial to understanding the film's complex message about acceptance. 

Additionally, please proofread your essay for the following areas: 

possessive markers (e.g., Despite the film Another Round's initial positive...)
preposition (e.g., The dynamic shift results from Martin's) 
verb from (e.g., ...intake in his work life, he gave Martin...) 
article usage (e.g., in moderation without complete dependence).

Student Essay:

Hi Alejandra, 

Great job on this. Your interpretation of the final freeze-frame is excellent. Describing it as a decision to "embrace life even if he doesn't know what path lies ahead" perfectly captures the ambiguity and hope of that final shot. 

You stated that the result of the experiment was "them stopping." While they stop the formal experiment, Martin is clearly drinking alcohol in the final scene. It's important to note that the lesson isn't necessarily total abstinence, but rather a shift in why he drinks.

Overall, excellent job!

Student Essay: I feel that if I we to pick a scene within this film that would showcase the main character - Martin - as depressed or overall unmotivated, 6:25 in the first video is what I believe to be the best showcase of this. In this scene, Martin is overall very somber. He is at a stage in his life where he has made most of the large decisions within his life - now contemplating whether they were good or the right ones. Hi Christian, 

You introduced a very interesting concept: nostalgia as a trap. You correctly identified that he was idealizing a past that maybe wasn't as perfect as he remembers. 

However, your argument should be grounded in evidence. In the final scene, Martin is dancing on the harbor right after his best friend's funeral; he isn't ignoring the pain, he is choosing to embrace the "spark" of life despite the pain. Student Essay:
Throughout Another Round, we watch as the main character, Martin,
experiments with consuming more and more alcohol in an attempt to regain the
liveliness and confidence he once had as a young man. Before the start of this
experiment, Martin is simply going through the motions, perfunctorily performing his
duties required by his family and his job. This is especially clear at minute 5:00, when
Martin is lecturing to his class in a monotonous manner, he trails off from his initial
points and has to be corrected by his students, who are less than pleased with his
passionless teaching methods. As he begins drinking on the job, Martin transforms into
a completely new person. This evolution is illustrated best by minute 49:45, when
Martin engages the class in a passionate discussion about alcohol consumption,
connecting similarities between the students’ use and the use of famous historical
figures. Martin’s newfound, and borderline obsession, with drinking seems to pervade
his teaching, with each lesson having explicit ties to excessive alcohol use. Martin begins
taking a more involved approach to teaching, seeking common ground with his students
to reach them better, and, as a result, feels more fulfilled by his profession.
While initially it may seem like the drinking has fostered this change of spirit
within Martin, it is less about the alcohol itself and more about what it has enabled him
to do. Before this experiment, Martin was a passive participant in his life, and he feels he
has lost all drive, not just career-wise but within his relationships. The constant drinking

limits his inhibitions, and he allows himself to engage with life and others in ways he
never had before. As the film progresses, Martin recognizes thatit is not the alcohol that
has helped him become more present; it is the way he has actively chosen to start living,
to start finding happiness in his day-to-day life and his personal relationships. Overall,
the message Another Round wants its viewers to take away is that life is what you make
of it. It is up to you to seek out the joy in life, to take charge, and to find the meaning in
the mundane. Life is worth living, but only if you make it so.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Gray, 

This is a strong analysis. You did a great job contrasting the two classroom scenes. Showing how his teaching style shifted from "monotonous" to "passionate" is the best way to track the experiment's initial success. 

You argue that Martin learns to "find happiness in his day-to-day life," which is true, but the film ends with a tragedy (Tommy's death) followed by a chaotic celebration. Addressing how Martin reconciles that grief with the joy of the final dance would have added the necessary depth to your conclusion. 

Lastly, be careful with small typos and run-on sentences. 

Overall, great job!

Student Essay:
At the beginning of Another Round, you can sense and feel the portrayal of Martin as

You wrote a great thematic summary of the film. You correctly identified that Martin's problem wasn't sadness but a desire for control. 

However, be careful with your citations. You referred to the final graduation scene as Video 2, but it appears in Video 4 (starting at 18 minutes). Additionally, try to reconcile your conclusion with the fact that Martin is drinking in the final shot; that would add depth to your analysis.

Student Essay:
Drinking is an extremely addictive habit that many fall into whether it's being
introduced to it at a young age, or going through a hard moment in your life where you
need to find a way to forget about everything and relax. In Another Round, at the
beginning of the film we see that Martin is going through a tough life. He isn’t having
much enjoyment teaching, he doesn’t have a passionate relationship with his life, and
overall he believes he has become boring. His depression is not presented as a result of
one single event, but rather as a slow erosion of meaning, confidence, and emotional
engagement. A scene that demonstrates his depression would be at the very beginning at
4 minutes and 55 seconds. This scene shows his lack of passion for his profession and
how disconnected he is with his students and job. Additionally, at 6 minutes and 35
seconds, he asks his wife if he has become bored, this question further unraveles the
depression he has been feeling inside.
The film then turns into an alcohol experiment amongst four teachers, Martin included.
While alcohol is framed as dangerous as shown at the beginning of the first clip up to 3
minutes and 30 seconds where the student had gotten so out of control the consumption
of alcohol had to be banned during that semester. It functions as a tool that lowers
Martin's defenses, meaning under the influence he becomes more expressive, a more
energetic and dynamic teacher, and finds the missing passion with his wife again. An
example of where Martin shows a transformation is in the second clip at 19 minutes and
51 seconds to 23 minutes and 23 seconds, this scene reveals Martin's locked away
passion for teaching and it demonstrates him at his happiest point where even the students
who previously complained about him are cheering him on. However, As the experiment
escalates and the men begin consuming an outrageous amount of alcohol the negative
consequences become unavoidable, through the tragic suicide ot Tommy. This contrast
reinforces that alcohol is not the true solution to existential dissatisfaction. Instead, it
exposes the underlying human desire to escape numbness and to feel alive, something
Martin had been craving for, for a long time. For Martin, the tragedy forces a deeper
understanding that he must confront grief, responsibility and loss without the safety of
intoxication. This is where his growth becomes more authentic, since he is no longer

relying on alcohol to control his emotions he is facing life directly as he should’ve been
all these years.
The final scene of the film (21 minutes and 10 seconds), crystallizes his transformation as
he is seen dancing at graduation celebration. Although, at first glance it seems to just be a
dance, the dance is jazz ballet, a part of Martin that he locked away and through this
scene symbolizes how he reclaimed this lost part of himself. As dancing was a huge part
of his earlier life, this expresses how he is reconnecting with his identity. Additionally, he
is seen rebuilding a relationship with Anika after all the reserved years they spent
together. The broader message of this film is about life and how living is complex. The
film does not present a simple lesson that alcohol is either good or bad but instead uses
alcohol as a metaphor for the human desire to loosen control and feel more intensely
alive. The final message suggests that modern life often encourages emotional restraints,
routine, and excessive self-monitoring which can lead to people feeling and becoming
numb. I believe the film argues that life requires emotional risk, vulnerability and
willingness to experience pleasure and pain. Martin's growth reflects the idea that living
fully means choosing to participate in life more fully rather than being “invisible” as
Anika stated. Another Round demonstrates that to live life you must take risks,
experience emotions, and connect within the world rather than succumbing to alcohol.
Teacher Feedback:
Hi Kseniya, 

This is a fantastic essay in terms of content. You did an excellent job describing Martin's depression and analyzing the jazz ballet scene. Just be careful about claiming he is "no longer relying on alcohol" at the end. Since he is drinking throughout the final celebration, the final message is likely more about balance or acceptance than total sobriety. 

However, it is way too long. You are well over the 400-word limit. Being able to edit your thoughts down to the essential arguments is a critical skill. For your next assignments, focus on analyzing the scenes rather than retelling them. 

Lastly, be careful with some typos and run-on sentences. I've left comments directly on your submission. 

Overall, good work.
